question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Compute the sum and enter your answer as a common fraction:
$$
\begin{array}{r r@{}c@{}l}
& 1 &.& 11111111\ldots \\
& 0 &.& 11111111\ldots \\
& 0 &.& 01111111\ldots \\
& 0 &.& 00111111\ldots \\
& 0 &.& 00011111\ldots \\
& 0 &.& 00001111\ldots \\
& 0 &.& 00000111\ldots \\
+ &&\vdots \\
\hline
&&& ~~~?
\end{array}
$$
inference:
Let $S = 1.111111\ldots + 0.111111\ldots + 0.011111\ldots + 0.001111\ldots + 0.000111\ldots + \dots$
The $n$-th term in the sum is
$0.\underbrace{00\ldots0}_{n-1}111\ldots1 = \frac{1}{10^{n-1}} \times \frac{1}{9} (10 - 1 + \frac{1}{10} (10 - 1) + (\frac{1}{10})^2(10 - 1) + \dots ) = \frac{1}{10^{n-1}} \times \frac{1}{9}(1 + \frac{1}{10} + (\frac{1}{10})^2 + (\frac{1}{10})^3 + \dots)$
$= \frac{1}{10^{n-1}} \times \frac{1}{9} \left(\frac{1}{1 - \frac{1}{10}}\right) = \frac{1}{10^{n-1}} \times \frac{1}{9} \times \frac{10}{9} = \frac{1}{9} \times \frac{10}{9} \times \frac{1}{10^{n-1}} = \frac{10}{81} \times \frac{1}{10^{n-1}} = \frac{1}{81 \times 10^{n-2}}$
The sum is $S = 1.111\ldots + 0.111\ldots + 0.011\ldots + \ldots = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{1}{10^n} \sum_{k=0}^\infty \frac{1}{10^k} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \sum_{k=n}^\infty \frac{1}{10^n} \frac{1}{10^k} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{1}{9 \times 10^{2n-1}} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{1}{9} \times \frac{1}{10^{n}} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{1}{10^{n-1}} \times \frac{1}{9} \times \frac{1}{1 - \frac{1}{10}} = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{1}{9} \times \frac{1}{10^{n-1}} = \frac{1}{1 - \frac{1}{10}} = \frac{10}{9}$
So $S = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{1}{10^n} \left( \frac{1}{10^n} \times \frac{1}{9} \right) = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{1}{9} \frac{1}{10^n} + \frac{1}{9} \frac{1}{10^{2n}} + \dots = 1. \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{10^n \times 10^n} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty 10^n \left( \sum_{k=n}^\infty \frac{1}{10^{n+k}} \right) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{9} (\frac{1}{10^{n-1}}) = \frac{1}{9}\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{10^{n-1}} = \frac{1}{9} \times \frac{1}{1 - 1/10} = \frac{1}{9} \times \frac{10}{9} = \frac{10}{81} (10^{-(n-1)}) = \frac{10}{81 \times 10^{n-2}}$
$1 + \frac{1}{9} + \frac{1}{9} (\frac{1}{10}) + \dots = 1 + \frac{1}{10 \times 9} = \frac{1}{9} + \frac{1}{90} + \dots = \frac{1}{9}(1 + \frac{1}{10}) = 1 + \frac{1}{10} \times \frac{1}{1 - 1/10} = 1 + \frac{1}{9} + \frac{1}{90} + \dots = \frac{1}{9} \times 10/9 = 1.2222...$
Final Answer: $\boxed{\frac{1}{9}}$
ground_truth:
The first addend, $1.11111111\ldots$, is by itself equal to the sum of the infinite geometric series
$$1+\frac 1{10}+\left(\frac 1{10}\right)^2+\left(\frac 1{10}\right)^3+\cdots,$$which is $\frac 1{1-\frac 1{10}}=\frac{10}9$.

The second addend is one-tenth of this, so equals $\frac 19$. The third addend is one-tenth of the second addend, and so on. Thus the sum of the infinite column of infinite decimals is
\begin{align*}
\frac{10}9\cdot\left[1+\frac 1{10}+\left(\frac 1{10}\right)^2+\cdots\right] &= \frac{10}9\cdot\frac{10}9 \\
&= \boxed{\frac{100}{81}}.
\end{align*}Notice that we have just added $1+\frac 2{10}+\frac 3{100}+\frac 4{1000}+\cdots$, sneakily.

question:
Let $S = 1.111111\ldots + 0.111111\ldots + 0.011111\ldots + 0.001111\ldots + 0.000111\ldots + \dots$
The $n$-th term in the sum is
$0.\underbrace{00\ldots0}_{n-1}111\ldots1 = \frac{1}{10^{n-1}} \times \frac{1}{9} (10 - 1 + \frac{1}{10} (10 - 1) + (\frac{1}{10})^2(10 - 1) + \dots ) = \frac{1}{10^{n-1}} \times \frac{1}{9}(1 + \frac{1}{10} + (\frac{1}{10})^2 + (\frac{1}{10})^3 + \dots)$
$= \frac{1}{10^{n-1}} \times \frac{1}{9} \left(\frac{1}{1 - \frac{1}{10}}\right) = \frac{1}{10^{n-1}} \times \frac{1}{9} \times \frac{10}{9} = \frac{1}{9} \times \frac{10}{9} \times \frac{1}{10^{n-1}} = \frac{10}{81} \times \frac{1}{10^{n-1}} = \frac{1}{81 \times 10^{n-2}}$
The sum is $S = 1.111\ldots + 0.111\ldots + 0.011\ldots + \ldots = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{1}{10^n} \sum_{k=0}^\infty \frac{1}{10^k} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \sum_{k=n}^\infty \frac{1}{10^n} \frac{1}{10^k} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{1}{9 \times 10^{2n-1}} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{1}{9} \times \frac{1}{10^{n}} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{1}{10^{n-1}} \times \frac{1}{9} \times \frac{1}{1 - \frac{1}{10}} = \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{1}{9} \times \frac{1}{10^{n-1}} = \frac{1}{1 - \frac{1}{10}} = \frac{10}{9}$
So $S = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{1}{10^n} \left( \frac{1}{10^n} \times \frac{1}{9} \right) = \sum_{n=0}^\infty \frac{1}{9} \frac{1}{10^n} + \frac{1}{9} \frac{1}{10^{2n}} + \dots = 1. \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{10^n \times 10^n} = \sum_{n=0}^\infty 10^n \left( \sum_{k=n}^\infty \frac{1}{10^{n+k}} \right) = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{9} (\frac{1}{10^{n-1}}) = \frac{1}{9}\sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{10^{n-1}} = \frac{1}{9} \times \frac{1}{1 - 1/10} = \frac{1}{9} \times \frac{10}{9} = \frac{10}{81} (10^{-(n-1)}) = \frac{10}{81 \times 10^{n-2}}$
$1 + \frac{1}{9} + \frac{1}{9} (\frac{1}{10}) + \dots = 1 + \frac{1}{10 \times 9} = \frac{1}{9} + \frac{1}{90} + \dots = \frac{1}{9}(1 + \frac{1}{10}) = 1 + \frac{1}{10} \times \frac{1}{1 - 1/10} = 1 + \frac{1}{9} + \frac{1}{90} + \dots = \frac{1}{9} \times 10/9 = 1.2222...$
Final Answer: $\boxed{\frac{1}{9}}$
There might be an error in the solution above because of lack of understanding of the question. Please correct the error, if any, and rewrite the solution. Only output the final solution \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
inference:
The $n$-th term in the sum is $\frac{1}{10^{n-1}} \times \frac{1}{9}$.  The sum is
$$S = \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{10^{n-1}} \times \frac{1}{9} = \frac{1}{9} \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} \frac{1}{10^{n-1}} = \frac{1}{9} \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{1}{10^n} = \frac{1}{9} \left( 1 + \frac{1}{10} + \frac{1}{10^2} + \dots \right) = \frac{1}{9} \left( \frac{1}{1-\frac{1}{10}} \right) = \frac{1}{9} \left( \frac{10}{9} \right) = \frac{10}{81}.$$

Thus,
$$S = 1.1111... + 0.1111... + 0.0111... + 0.0011... + \dots = \frac{1}{9} (1 + \frac{1}{10} + \frac{1}{10^2} + \dots) + \frac{1}{10} \frac{1}{9}(1 + \frac{1}{10} + \dots) + \frac{1}{10^2}\frac{1}{9}(1 + \dots) + \dots$$
$$ = \sum_{k=0}^\infty \frac{1}{10^k}\frac{1}{9} = \frac{1}{9}\left(\frac{1}{1-1/10}\right) = \frac{1}{9}\left(\frac{10}{9}\right) = \frac{10}{81}.$$

The $n$th term is $\frac{1}{10^{n-1}} \times \frac{1}{9} = \frac{1}{9 \times 10^{n-1}}$.
$$ S = \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{9 \times 10^{n-1}} = \frac{1}{9} \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac{1}{10^{n-1}} = \frac{1}{9} \left( \frac{1}{1 - \frac{1}{10}} \right) = \frac{1}{9} \left( \frac{10}{9} \right) = \frac{10}{81}.$$

Final Answer: The final answer is $\boxed{10/81}$
ground_truth:
The first addend, $1.11111111\ldots$, is by itself equal to the sum of the infinite geometric series
$$1+\frac 1{10}+\left(\frac 1{10}\right)^2+\left(\frac 1{10}\right)^3+\cdots,$$which is $\frac 1{1-\frac 1{10}}=\frac{10}9$.

The second addend is one-tenth of this, so equals $\frac 19$. The third addend is one-tenth of the second addend, and so on. Thus the sum of the infinite column of infinite decimals is
\begin{align*}
\frac{10}9\cdot\left[1+\frac 1{10}+\left(\frac 1{10}\right)^2+\cdots\right] &= \frac{10}9\cdot\frac{10}9 \\
&= \boxed{\frac{100}{81}}.
\end{align*}Notice that we have just added $1+\frac 2{10}+\frac 3{100}+\frac 4{1000}+\cdots$, sneakily.
